overview.title: What are Compound Nouns?
overview.description: Compound nouns are nouns made up of two or more words that function together as a single noun. They form new words by combining nouns, adjectives, verbs, or prepositions.
key_points: Formed by combining two or more words
Can be written as one word, hyphenated, or as separate words
The meaning of a compound noun is often different from the individual words
Help expand vocabulary and describe specific objects or concepts
overview.importance: Understanding compound nouns broadens learners' ability to recognize and use complex noun forms found in everyday language.

sections.title: Definition and Types
sections.content: A compound noun combines two or more words to create a noun that has a meaning different from the original words separately. There are three main types: closed (one word), hyphenated, and open (spaced) compound nouns.

subsections.subtitle: Closed Compound Nouns
subsections.text: Words joined together without spaces or hyphens, such as 'toothbrush' and 'sunflower'.

subsections.subtitle: Hyphenated Compound Nouns
subsections.text: Words joined with a hyphen, like 'mother-in-law' and 'editor-in-chief'.

subsections.subtitle: Open Compound Nouns
subsections.text: Words written separately but function as a single noun, such as 'ice cream' and 'bus stop'.

sections.title: Formation Rules
sections.content: Compound nouns often combine nouns with nouns, adjectives with nouns, verbs with nouns, or nouns with prepositions. The main noun (headword) usually determines the plural form.

subsections.subtitle: Common Combinations
subsections.text: Noun + Noun: 'football', Adjective + Noun: 'full moon', Verb + Noun: 'washing machine', Noun + Preposition: 'mother-in-law'.

subsections.subtitle: Pluralization
subsections.text: The plural is made by adding 's' to the main noun (e.g., 'toothbrushes', 'mothers-in-law').

sections.title: Usage in Sentences
sections.content: Compound nouns function as any noun does. Knowing their form helps learners read, write, and understand new vocabulary clearly.

subsections.subtitle: Examples
subsections.text: You can say: 'She bought a toothbrush.', 'My mother-in-law is visiting.', 'We played basketball yesterday.'

grammar_rules.title: Types of Compound Nouns
grammar_rules.description: There are three types: closed (one word), hyphenated, and open (two or more words separated by spaces).
grammar_rules.tip: Learn to recognize types based on spelling and usage.

grammar_rules.title: Plural Formation
grammar_rules.description: To form the plural, add 's' to the main noun word, which is typically the last noun or the most important word.
grammar_rules.tip: Identify the main noun to pluralize correctly.

grammar_rules.title: Meaning Changes
grammar_rules.description: The meaning of a compound noun is often different from its individual parts; context is important.
correct_examples: 'toothbrush' is not just 'tooth' + 'brush' but a tool for cleaning teeth.
incorrect_examples: Treating compound nouns as separate words that describe unrelated things.
grammar_rules.tip: Remember compound nouns create new meanings.

grammar_rules.title: Capitalization
grammar_rules.description: Only capitalize compound proper nouns or if they begin a sentence. Common compound nouns are lowercase.

grammar_rules.title: Hyphen Use
grammar_rules.description: Hyphenate compound nouns when they include prefixes like 'mother-in-law' or when clarity requires it.
grammar_rules.tip: Use hyphens for clarity and set compound nouns.

examples.sentence: She packed her toothbrush for the trip.
examples.analysis: 'Toothbrush' is a closed compound noun naming an object.

examples.sentence: I parked near the bus stop.
examples.analysis: 'Bus stop' is an open compound noun indicating a location.

examples.sentence: My mother-in-law is very kind.
examples.analysis: 'Mother-in-law' is a hyphenated compound noun naming a family member.

examples.sentence: We enjoyed ice cream after dinner.
examples.analysis: 'Ice cream' is an open compound noun naming a dessert.

examples.sentence: He bought a new basketball yesterday.
examples.analysis: 'Basketball' is a closed compound noun naming a sport.

examples.sentence: The post office is closed today.
examples.analysis: 'Post office' is an open compound noun naming a location.

examples.sentence: They live near the classroom.
examples.analysis: 'Classroom' is a closed compound noun naming a place.

examples.sentence: He works at the editor-in-chief's office.
examples.analysis: 'Editor-in-chief' is a hyphenated compound noun naming a position.

examples.sentence: The dining table was set for dinner.
examples.analysis: 'Dining table' is an open compound noun.

examples.sentence: Please enter the bedroom quietly.
examples.analysis: 'Bedroom' is a closed compound noun for a room.

examples.sentence: Swimming pools are popular in summer.
examples.analysis: 'Swimming pool' is an open compound noun.

examples.sentence: I bought a new football.
examples.analysis: 'Football' is a closed compound noun.

examples.sentence: Her full moon party was unforgettable.
examples.analysis: 'Full moon' is an open compound noun.

examples.sentence: He enjoys watching the basketball game.
examples.analysis: 'Basketball' is a closed compound noun.

examples.sentence: The washing machine broke down.
examples.analysis: 'Washing machine' is an open compound noun.

examples.sentence: The blackboard was covered in chalk writing.
examples.analysis: 'Blackboard' is a closed compound noun.

examples.sentence: She has a beautiful birdhouse in her garden.
examples.analysis: 'Birdhouse' is a closed compound noun.

examples.sentence: We celebrated on Thanksgiving Day.
examples.analysis: 'Thanksgiving Day' is an open compound noun, often a proper noun.

examples.sentence: The sister-in-law made dinner for the family.
examples.analysis: 'Sister-in-law' is a hyphenated compound noun.

examples.sentence: He loves reading the newspaper every morning.
examples.analysis: 'Newspaper' is a closed compound noun.

complex_sentences.sentence: The mother-in-law brought a birthday cake from the bakery.
complex_sentences.analysis: The hyphenated compound noun 'mother-in-law' names a family member.

complex_sentences.sentence: After school, the children played basketball near the post office.
complex_sentences.analysis: 'Basketball' and 'post office' are compound nouns used to describe activities and places.

complex_sentences.sentence: She left her toothbrush and swimming pool towel at the hotel.
complex_sentences.analysis: Closed and open compound nouns name objects and places.

common_mistakes.explanation: In hyphenated compounds, pluralize the main noun (mothers).
common_mistakes.tip: Pluralize the important noun part in hyphenated compounds.
Use hyphens for clarity and meaning.

common_mistakes.explanation: Closed compounds must be written as a single word.
common_mistakes.tip: Learn closed compound spellings as single words.

common_mistakes.wrong: Black board is used in class.
common_mistakes.explanation: Compound nouns have different meanings from separate words.
common_mistakes.tip: Treat compound nouns as single concepts.

common_mistakes.explanation: Only capitalize proper nouns or sentence start.
Only pluralize the main noun, not the whole phrase.
common_mistakes.tip: Focus on pluralizing the main noun only.

common_mistakes.explanation: Open compounds must have a space between words.

common_mistakes.error_type: Using compound as adjective without hyphen
common_mistakes.explanation: Compound adjectives before nouns usually need a hyphen.

identification.instructions: Underline the compound nouns in each sentence.

questions.explanation: 'Ice cream' is an open compound noun.

questions.explanation: 'Post office' is an open compound noun.

correction.title: Correct the Common Compound Noun Errors
correction.instructions: Correct the errors in underlined compound nouns.

questions.sentence: I bought two mother in laws.
questions.explanation: Hyphenate and pluralize only the main noun.
Write closed compounds as one word.

answer: We saw an ice cream truck.

questions.sentence: He is a well known actor.

questions.explanation: Only capitalize at sentence start or for proper nouns.
